header.gameNote: COACHES VS CANCER CLASSIC AT BJCC ARENA

article.description: Ontario Harper scored a career-high 17 points and Mississippi State (No. 14 ESPN/USA Today, No. 12 AP), playing without preseason All-America Lawrence Roberts, beat Fairfield 53-49 on Thursday night in the first round of the Coaches vs. Cancer Classic.
article.headline: Bulldogs played without preseason All-America Roberts
article.linkText: Mississippi State survives scare from Fairfield
article.story: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. (AP) -- Mississippi State coach Rick Stansbury wouldn't use the absence of Lawrence Roberts as an excuse for the Bulldogs' close call against Fairfield on Thursday night in the opening round of the Coaches vs. Cancer Classic. "It's very obvious that we're not quite as good without Lawrence Roberts," Stansbury said after the 53-49 scare against the Stags. "But we knew coming into this game that we didn't have him, so we can't make any excuse." Roberts, a senior forward, sat out because of a one-game suspension from the NCAA over his expenses to attend a tryout before the NBA draft. Reserve Ontario Harper scored 17 points for the Bulldogs (No. 14 ESPN/USA Today, No. 12 AP), who trailed by as many as eight points in the first half. The Bulldogs (1-0) will play Birmingham-Southern (1-0) in the second round on Friday night. Birmingham-Southern beat Alabama A&M 79-69 on Thursday. Winsome Frazier and Gary Ervin hit consecutive 3-pointers to give the Bulldogs a 47-39 lead with 1:44 to play. Frazier and Ervin both finished with nine points. Fairfield (0-1) got within three points in the closing seconds, but Harper made one of two free throws with 3 seconds left for the final margin. "Even without Roberts, Mississippi State is a really, really good team," Fairfield coach Tim O'Toole said. "We tried to play a perfect game and slow it down, but they beat us on the boards and made us shoot poorly." Deng Gai had 14 points and eight rebounds for Fairfield. Mississippi State shot just 28 percent in the first half, including 1-of-8 from 3-point range, as Fairfield took a 24-20 lead. The Bulldogs struggled to get in sync early, missing their first eight shots. The Stags' biggest lead of the game was 24-16 with 1:30 left in the first half.
